H0.text: ganglion axons forming the optic nerve run to the. Lateral Geniculate Nucleus

H1.text: ganglion axons forming the optic nerve run to the. Superior Colliculus

H2.text: ganglion axons forming the optic nerve run to the. Pretectal Area

H3.text: ganglion axons forming the optic nerve run to the. optic chiasma

A4.text: In mammals they also branch off to the lateral geniculate body of the thalamus, in turn giving them to the occipital cortex of the cerebrum.

A5.text: The optic tract inserts on the optic tectum (in mammals known as superior colliculus) of the midbrain.

A6.text: In humans, the optic nerve is derived from optic stalks during the seventh week of development and is composed of retinal ganglion cell axons and glial cells; it extends from the optic disc to the optic chiasma and continues as the optic tract to the lateral geniculate nucleus, pretectal nuclei, and superior colliculus.

A7.text: Other axons terminate in the pretectal area and are involved in reflexive eye movements.
